entities.description: The respondent has tried and was unable to cut down or stop drinking alcohol.
The respondent spent a great deal of time drinking alcohol, feeling its effects, or getting over the effects of drinking.
The respondent wanted to use alcohol so badly they could not think of anything else or had a strong urge to use alcohol.
The respondent had serious problems at work, school, or home related to alcohol use.
The respondent had problems with family or friends caused or made worse by alcohol use.
The respondent gave up or spent less time doing important social, occupational, or recreational activities due to alcohol use.
Alcohol use led the respondent into situations where drinking increased their chances of getting physically hurt.
The respondent continued to use alcohol even though it was causing problems with emotions, mental health, or physical health.
The respondent needed to drink a lot more alcohol to get the desired effect or drinking the same amount had less effect.
The respondent reported experiencing two or more alcohol withdrawal symptoms after alcohol use was cut back or stopped.

relationships.description: Relates the respondent's attempt to cut down or stop drinking alcohol.
Links the respondent to the time spent dealing with the effects of alcohol use.
Connects the respondent's strong urge or compulsion to use alcohol.
Indicates the respondent faced serious issues at work, school, or home due to alcohol use.
Links the respondent's family or friend problems to their alcohol use.
Indicates the respondent faced social, occupational, or recreational consequences due to alcohol use.
Shows that alcohol use increased the respondent's risk of physical harm.
Indicates the respondent's continued alcohol use despite mental or physical health problems.
Links the respondent to increased alcohol consumption needed to achieve the desired effect.
Shows the respondent experienced withdrawal symptoms after reducing or stopping alcohol use.
